												If you've not played Magic in over a decade and want to tap some mana, this may just be the game you want to pick up. Here, you get a number of decks to play with, several modes and styles of play including multiplayer.Things to keep in mind:You won't find cards from the early era of magic you may recall from ages past. Alpha, beta, The Dark, Arabian Nights? Unlimited, & 3rd edtion? Not here. What you will find are a selection of decks from moderan 2013 era magic. What matters however is that you are given numerous ways to play the game and a number of various decks to mess around with.You can buy this with a number of unlocks set, or with all cards unlocked. The locked variant might be for you if you enjoy the challenge of unlocking cards and the related achievement pleasure that can be had from unlocking. If you just want to play with cards, as many as you can get your mits on (without grinding) - you may want the 'Complete' edition.At worst, in this release you can't build decks from an entirely raw ensemble of cards. You can however heavily modify the numerous decks that you are given. Most of these decks have anywhere from 30 to 40 specific deck limited extra cards that can be added or used to replace default deck setups to modify your style of play. Despite these official limitations of the 2013 M:tG game, there is actually something of a modding scene. Google for mods and you may just stumble into what you want if you really want to build decks from scratch / have minor game play bugs fixed.A very minor user specific issue that can be disabled: Foil cards. IRL they're entertaining and in the game you can have them too. Yet they're animated and constantly glimmer. The constant animation can become a little irritating, turning a novelty special card into a literal headache. Fortunately, - the game has an option to remove the appearance of foil on all foil cards.So, all in all this is a solidly entertaining version of Magic to mess around with on a computer. Be it offline multiplayer locally, online multiplayer, or in single player vs. AI's of varying difficulties.

Magic the Gathering - Duels of the Planeswalkers 2013If you're new to Magic, this is a great place to start. I decided to try this after a friend introduced me to the actual card game, which I found surprisingly entertaining and so decided to try my luck with the video game. What drew me into the game in general was the artwork, and it still fascinates me how this simple but effective illustration style manages to make the action jump right off the table. As a complete newcomer, whereas more advanced players understandably criticised them, Duels' limitations felt like positives to me, where an unrestricted version of the game could have made things prohibitively complex. The only negative I can find personally is the shocking amount of attempts at monetisation.Pros:Stunning fantasy artwork and sleek user interface;Mechanics are easy to learn, but the game itself hard to master;Single-player campaign's gradual learning curve adequately prepares inexperienced players for more challenging encounters;Clever puzzle scenarios are a nice break from the regular game while continuing to teach useful strategies;Overall simplified approach of Duels is perfect for new players.Neutral:Very simple narrative thread serves its purpose;Ready-made decks and limited customisation possibilities help level the playing field;Background soundtrack is subtle enough that it stays fresh for a while.Cons:Inordinate amount of attempts at monetisation;Some questionable AI decisions at higher levels.

Posted: August 22, 2013
												Riding on the success of DotP 2012's improvements, the 2013 release introduces revamped decks, a new unlock system, and a new game mode. While 2013 has less decks available (16 versus last year's 19), they are overall more accessible for quick play because of the 10 promo unlocks provided post-release. The decks are also more balanced in power overall because you aren't locked out of the best cards anymore. However, this is a double-edged sword; While you can unlock a total of 40 cards per deck, many of them are dups and you can only unlock one at a time. To put this into perspective, beating the first campaign (the longest in the game) will unlock 26 cards.While I enjoyed the difficult challenges (the hardest challenges of the DotP games in my opinion), this game is riddled with issues that will never get fixed or improved since the devs have moved onto their next yearly release. Locking out all but two decks at the start is a terrible way to introduce new players to MTG, especially considering the target market for these games. The one new game mode, Planechase, is only worth playing with friends; The AI is terrible at it, seeming to attack and roll the planar die randomly. Despite being marketed towards new and casual players, this game can only be recommended for experienced MTG players because of the unlock systems and frustration with non-human Planechase.

												Although no where near as diverse as the actual table top trading card game, where you can use ANY cards you have in a much more social setting, this is a great electronic verson of the Magic the Gathering. For only $10 (not counting optional DLC), you can play with several decks of every colour in a campaign, in custom games against A.I., or with friends in several game types. The DLC offer allows anyone to purchase extra decks too, again for a fairly low price (especially during steam sales. :D).The deck building is pretty basic too. You have a set series of cards for every deck and the mana is automatically added for you. Although this can be a pain at times to those who (like me) have been playing for years and like to play around with little things like that, it is perfect for new players who only wanna focus on getting "the best cards" into their deck.The only REAL complaint I have is the game timer. While this does make sense for being a PC game, the timer is too long in some moments and too short in others, making the game speed and attention to detail needed very out of flux at times. One of the best Magic games along with the 2014 versionPROS:- The decks are incredibly well balanced. Almost all decks feels equally powerful. To begin with many of the decks will feel very weak but they get much stronger as you progress and unlock all cards. I have unlocked every single card in the game and I consider the 2013 version to be absolute best Magic game in terms of balancing. - A lot of different variety of amazing decks to suit your playstyle. All feel great as they get full unlocked and tweaked to perfection.- Plane Chase (not in the later versions): This game mode is essentially is a regular 2, 3 or 4 player FFA which you battle across a variety of diverse worlds, each with its own unique effect on the game. This makes the game unpredictable as it can quickly turn the tables. This game is pretty fun but does not seem very balanced. For instance if you encounter the plane called Jund, you better prepare to get steamrolled very fast if you are a non-green, non-black, non-red colour player and your enemy is. CONS:- Virtually no one playing the game online. If you want to play against other players online, the 2014 and 2015 is still the best options. 2014 will mostly be Two-Headed Giants mode. 2015 lacks Two-Headed Giants mode but will have better chances of finding FFA games. But the game is absolutely amazing if you have friends playing it.This version plays slower than the 2014 and 2015 version. It will not play as swift and responsive as the later versions. The longer wait between turns is a little annoying.BUG: Deck "Peacekeepers" does not seem to unlock cards properly. You can unlock the first 10 cards with a promo code. The rest will unlock as you win games but as soon as you exit the game, the unlocked cards will be lost. This can be fixed if you go to the "Deck Manager" and make a small change before clicking "Back" and then save the changes. CONCLUSION: I would definately recommend this game despite it's flaws. I would say I slightly prefer the overall play of 2014 version but this is still one the best Magic: DotP. Better than 2015 and MUCH better than the new free Magic Duels, which is an atrocity to be perfectly honest. If you are new to Magic Duels of the Planeswalkers and have yet to decide which version to try, I would recommend the 2014 version first for the above reasons. There are not exactly a lot of players playing it, but you can often find Two-Headed Giants games in 2014 version. This does not seem to be the case in this version. A real shame because it has some really kickass decks. Keep in mind that this game is very rarely on sale. If you see it on sale you should buy it.

The decks that you are provided with all begin with just a subset of the full deck. To get the cards that you are missing, you must win battles with that deck. Cards are unlocked one at a time and it feels extremely long to unlock all cards. So to resume, let's say it's a nice magic but very limited in terms of replayability. So my advice is: Buy this game if it's really cheap, say 5$. You'll then get enough entertainment from this game for your 5$. But otherwise, the game will quickly feel like it's missing some features that were deliberatly locked in order to include that content in Downloadable Content (DLC). Posted: July 16, 2012
												If you are into Magic: The Gathering, you'll love this.I have some slight gripes about weird glitches that happen such as computer attacking when it's not their turn, planechase cards getting stuck at full zoom, other random things that happen when they shouldn't. Hopefully these problems will be fixed in updates of some sort.However, it's still an enjoyable experience overall.

Posted: April 22
												The game is balanced, has a wide variety of cards and playstyles. The drtawings are stunning and colourfull. Nevertheless, the bugs and crushes arrive pretty much every other game which is bizarre and unaccaptable for the game that was realised almost 5 years ago. The camera angle is sooo bad, the portatraits block half of the creen and the arid view makes the cards tiny and hardly visible.
